So frequent did duels become, that it is
said, in the short reign of Henry ". of
France, 1000 persons per!shed in duels.
Coke lays it down that duelling is strictly
contrary to the law Of England, and every
By -stander is enjoined to prevent duel. IT.,
in so doing, he injure the combatants, they
shall have no remedy at law; if he be hurt
by them, he shall have his redress, Not
wthstandins this, duelling in England was
carried to its greatest possible excess, IN


the reigns of James |. and ofthe two Charles'.
In the reign of the latter Charles, the Sc
conds always fought as well as their princl-


pals; and as they were chosen for their cour-
age and adrotness, their combats were gen


erally the most fatal. We read that Lord
Howard, of Carlisle, in the reign of Charles
II. gave grand fete chanpetre, at Spring
Gardens, near the village Of Charing. Spring
Gardens, was the Vauxhall of that day, and
the tete, in question was given to facilitate
an intrigue between Lord Howard and the

"Jenny," said country woman to her
buxom daughter, during one OF the warm
mornings CT last summer, "Jennv, yen ava
to the town and bring hame battle o BARN
Tyeast1 wi you." 1t was the preaching days
with Jenny, aud having "trysted to meet her
Joe," she nodded an assent to her mother
commands, with a beam i'll her eye that
bespoke as much of, love as obedience
Having accordingly lost no time In display
ing her charms to the best advantage, she
plunged the quart bottle in among the sun
dries which never fail to occupy the capa
cious receptacle denominated by country
damsels, sidepocket, and so smartiy trip
ped her way to town, that she was halt way
on her return before the sun reached his
meridian. Whether it was that Jenny had
been seized with more than ordinary feelings
Of devotion, or that the willy god, being i'll a
frolicksome humour, had resolved on play
ing off one OF his pranks upon her. we shall
not pretend to say, but certain 1t is that
Jenny, on her way homewards, was just
passing the kirk as she got glimpse OF her
Joe stepping into it Regardless otthe we'll
corked bottle Of BARN, Jenny nstinctlvely
pursued the same course, and sat herself
down beside blowsy wife from Dollar, who
had travelled a dozen miles that morning to
hear the word in its purity, if not to retail
! it still more delectabiy, on her return, to the
drowthy gossps of her parish. Jenny had
scarcely time to look about her till the va
cant seat behind her was occupied by an e.
qually ponderous parsonage, in the shape OF
a horse couper's wife from the West. Had
Jenny been thinking more of her mother, and
less of her sweetheart, it is likely that il
would have occurred to her that so smart a
walk, and SO warm day, were sufficient te
have reused to a state of rebellion more
ouiescept matter than that which dangled by
her side, and in this way avoided bringing
its heat to the provoking temperature i'll.
duced by her own temperature on the one
side and that of the horse couper's wife OF
the other. Be these things as they may, the
heat which had commenced to seal Jenny:
eyes in peaceful slumbers, acted so power
fully on the turbulent properties of the
BARN, that an explosion was inevitable

Ireland.


81 was aroused from one OF memory S
sweetest dreams, by the distant sound OF
bells; they were those OF my native city
| had often heard them at the same hour,
they spoke of wo, devotion, and Joy, and
scenes long gone BY. In this sottened state
of feeling entered the town, and needless
of the throng, hurried on to the home OF
my parents-reaching the house--threw
myself into their arnis, and the first tumult
of feeling over. / sat at tbs e-side. with my
father Oh the one side. and my mother on
the other, gazing afectionate'y upon me,
while talked of all had seen, and all had
felt.


"Beng tired after my journey, my mother
suggested the propriety OF my gong 10 resi-
and the tender hand that had often smooth
cd my pillow, again performed that oihce'
could not help comparing my situation
with the nights that | had lain exposed to
the storm. with the cold earth for my bed,
and felt a lively gratitude, (worth thou
sand formal prayers) to the Divine Bcing,
who had watched over and protected me
thro' every danger, and brought me in safe
ty back to my home and parents.


"NVhile nv mind was occupied with these
reflections, my mother again entered my
chamber to sec if / wanted any thing. Are
you asleep, James, My eyes were shut
and did not reply. She stood over me witt
light iii her hand, gazing on my weather
beaten countenance.


My poor want.erer, she calculated
what must you have endured since
saw you--danger and death has surrounded
YOU fatigue ard hunger attended your steps
| but vet YOU have been kindly dealt with
mercifully preserved return thee thanks
thou Almighty giver of every good, tor thy
bountcous mercy to my poor boy-O snlit
him to thyself" I"


She stopped to kiss my forehead-he'
warm tear fell upon my face, my emotions
became too strong for concealment, and a.
fraid that she had disturbed my sleep, she
softly left the room.


Those who have felt the rude storms o.
adversely. and the endearing kindness OF
mother, will appreciate my feelings

Men ALWAYS sympathise with the suffer-
ing of girls more than those other own sex.
"Reatlv. nv dear, | pity these poor girls,
the M'Tangles," said Mr. Partington to his
lady, as he peeped through his telescope on
the Margate Pier head, in the vain hope OF
catching little smoke in the horizon, from
which to infer the coming OF the Eclipse
steam vessel. "There they are broillng IN
town this whole blessed summer-you
should ask one OF them down." 30 saying,
Mr. Partington tilted his Chinese straw hat
little more over his brow to shade his eyes
from the burning glare of Phebus. "Wh ny
as to that, my dear" answered his wife, we
have daughters of our own to dispose OF -
and don't YOU remember how Sally VI Ian
| gle took the first in duett of Con un ARIA
with Colonel Nightingale, after he had tried
| it with our daughter Fanny, aud had found
that the poor girl could not get on with it'
I have never had good opinion OF the fam
| lily since" This, of course, settled the mat
ter.


A word with Mr.. Partington about his
phrase 'broiling in town. am a town man
myself, and think it my duty to stand up
for my own metropolis. Why should the
M'Tangles broil, because they happen to be
in town. For my part | can only say that
when was last at Ramsgate was broied
pretty handsomely. ! took walk upon the
! Lighthouse Pier, and light house pier 1t
was; nv face was like Lord Kelly's, whom
Foote solicited to lock over his garden wall
| to ripen his melons; Saint Laurence was a
sprat to me. On my return to town, took
a boat from Cherry Garden Stairs to White
hall; to do which had to walk down Bo-
tolph lane. The street was Delightfully."- mar
row, the sun could not enter, but a column
of air could; and I was regaled by the gar
den scent of oranges and lemons in the ad-
Joining warehouses. Let us hear no more ct
broiling in town. From that time forth |
have always set down my cause as Lon
don Remanet. The fact is. that Mrs.
M'Taugle has let me into her confidence,
knowing, that never published II met her
of all places in the world in private box at
Adelphia Theatre, witnessing the represen-
tation of Long Tom Coffin, by +. L. Cooke;
and very clever representation is. "You
never come near us now," eJaculated Mrs.
M'Tangle, in one of her most mellifluent
moods-Knowing that l was past praying
for in the matrimonial line, l felt puzzled
to account for this sudden predilection.--
However, it was settled that should dine
with her on the "Wednesday following. when
I accordingly met three or four young men
"a great deal too young for me, but by no
means too young for the Mesdemoisclles
M'Tangle. We had the usual lures. Tom
Gisbone, who had made good deal of mo-
ney by Mexican scrip, was asked by Miss
M'rangle if he would not have some love
sauce with his muffin pudding. George Ju
niper, rising wine and brandy merchant,
sang after dinner,


sMy spirits are mounting, my hearts full OF
glee,"-


(cause and effect in one line,) which Jane
M'Tangle pronounced to be the hest song
she ever heard in her life; and Sarah, the
youngest, undismayed by her former failure
in "Con un Aria," consented to take the first
in the "Witches' Glee," composed by King,
if Mr.. Parsons (son and heir to Sir Pere-
grine Parsons) would take the second.
found by comparing little circumstances to-

From the London Monthly Magazine.
LONDON REMANETS.

The following probably overchargeu, Dut
curious account of this eccentric character,
appears in Paris paper Some persons
knowing but imperfectly this model of ori-
ginals, past, present, and to conc, appear
ed desirous to learn something more re-
spccting him; we thinktit may be agreeable,
if we collect such anecdotes respecting such
a singular parsonage as are well calculated
to enrich the history Of human oddities. No
one has higher claims to distinguished
place IN history, than Nj. Egerton, who has
for several years borne the name ot Lord
Bridgewater. Those who have once seen--
nay, those who have never seen this measre
parsonage drag himself along, supported
by two huge lacqueys, with his sugar-loat
hat souched down over his eyes, cannot tall
to recognize him.


An immense fortune enables him to graf
ify the most eXtravagant caprice that ever
passed through the head of an Engishnan,
II he be lent a book, he carries his poltencss
so far as to send 1t back or rather have it
conducted home in carriage. He gives
orders that two of his most stately steeds be
caparisoned. under one of his chariots and the
volume reclining at ease in mylord's lacdau
arrives, attended BY four footmcn in costly
livery, at the door of its astounded owner
His carriage is frequently to be seen filled
with his dogs. lie bcstows great care on
the feet Of these dogs, and orders them boots
for which he pays as dearly as his own.--
| Lord BridgeWater's custom is an excellent
one for the boot ker; for besides the foul
feet OF each of his dogs, the supply OF hi'
own two feet, must give constant employ
ment to several operatives. He puts on {
new pair OF boots every day; carefully pre-
serving those he has once worn, and ranging
them in order; he commands that none
shall touch them, but takes himself grea
pleasure in observing how much OF the yeal
he has each day past, by viewing the state
of his boots. Lord Egerton is a man of few
acquaintance, and very few of his country
men have got as far as the dining hall. Hi
table, however, is constantly set out with ;
dozen covers, and served by suitable at
tendance. Who, then are his privileged
guests? No less than a dozen Of favorltt
dogs, who daily partake of mylord's dinner
J seated very gravely in armed chairs, eacf
with napkin round his neck, and scrvan
behind to attend his wants.


These honorable quadrupcds as if CRATE
full for such delicate attentions, compor
themselves during the time OF repast with
| decency and 0ecorum which would do more
than honor to party of gentlemen; but if
by any chance, one OF them should, wlthou
due consideration, obey the natural instnc
of his appetite, and transgress any OF the
rules Of good manners, his punishment is a
hand. You perhaps, gentle reader, sup
pose that corporeal punishment is meant al
the walls OF the capital so eloquently but 81
Intellectually define 1t; but no--you are mis-
taken, tits ia his sclf-Iove that the offendel


is punished. The day following the day O
his offence, the dog dimes and even dine


we'll; but not at mylord's, and as becomes ;
dog to dine; banished to the ante-chamber
and dressed in livery, he eats in sorrow thu
bread of shame, and picks the bones of NOR
tifcation, while his place at table remain
vacant till his repentance has merited
generous pardon We have not been abl


to learn what dress Lord Egerton puts ol
his domestics, when he has cause to be dis
satisfied with their service
THE EARL or BRlnGEwATER.

To get me out ofharm's way; and lett the

Mrs. M'Tanglc now let me little into

-"rhis is the third year of my continuance

| One warm morning was coming the mat

that Iondon in the autumn, from the absence
of competitors, would give the girls rea-
! snnable chance. i mentioned the matter to
Mr.. M'Tangle who caught at the idea with

side. The sun put ont his eyes, and the alb
sence Of his day book and ledger gave him
the yellow jaundcc. We accordingly re-
solved to adhere to Russell place, Fltzroy

men are delighted with dinner invitations IN
Scntember and October; and when you once
have them, you keep them" True, answer
! ed I but what species of young men? Peo.
nile Of fashion are killing game hundred
miles off. "people Of fashion, people OF fid-
die stick!' retorted Mrs. M'tansle. Al
/ have no taste tor the Lord CharleScs and
Lord Johns. Give me income. There is a
considerable portion of good marriageahle
material in the Excise and Customs, and a
bout the Royal Exchange. Peop'e occupied
there must be in town during great part OF
the autumnal season. have procured two
SONS in law, who came hither courting,
with their legs pendent from the top OF the
Tallyho Paddi1gton coach, their descent.
they had only to cross Fitzroy Square, and
here they were. You may rey upon it sir,
the true way of attaching society is to give
Rishy pfgflIy approve approve Of your plan, madam, an
swered j, rising to take my leave will re-
commend its adoption to Adrman Hunger
ford, now on his travels to Greece in quest
of Liberty and the picturesque. lie has
seven marriageabe daughters. Our young
counyrymen are fiocking to Athens in shoa $

aThe sun does not gladden. a moment so sweet
mo moon does not shine on so lovely an hour,
hsthe s,ft one where. light and obscurity meet,
And the world is half veiPd by its shadowy


power.
"Vhen the dew drops are glittering SO silent


and fair,


And the waters yet glow with the SUMS latest


ray,
Heaven breathcs It's repose in the calm twilight

Unknown to the brightness and tumult of day

er,
How balmy and sweet is the season of peace!

with the hopes of the future the light OF the


past;

sting;

Where is there vision sweeter


Than u boy and happy mother
lie makes her hours fly the fieeter:


She can all his sorrows smother.
What a look is that she gives him,


When he curves his arm around her!
Oh, her very soul receives him.


The bliss Of heaven sure has bound her!
Sec him lean his cheek, so smiling,


On her lap--and raise his lashes;
Mark bis hand, the time bcguiling,


With her ear-drop's dancing flashes.
Little knows the fair hard fellow,


She is asking God for blessings;
When her blossom, ripe, and mellow,


Will not have her kind caresslngs.
Little is that mother dreaming


Of his grief, when he must mingle,
Where no parent will be beamlng--


Where each heart is cold and single!
But, alas!-ne'r think of grieving,


While so sweet pictures glowing
Thoughts Of home we should be weaving
Pray'rs Of hope should now be howing!--

PasS'd often DER the basking snail.

why labor, insect, one would think

Thou art the most laborious worm:
me Caterpillar spins her clothes,

we we suck the rose unhurt by thorns,
Extract from blossoms affluent store,

Duchess, and distracted all her attentions
with his lordship; and ridiculing the tete, his
/ lordship was hardly restrained from running
him through the body before the company.
The next day his lordship sent challenge
to Sidney. The former chose as his second,
tell, furious, adroit swordsman, named
Dillon; and the latter selected young gen.
tleman, named Rawlings, just come into pos
session of an estate of ten thousand pounds
year.-Sidney was wounded i'll two OF
three places, whilst his second was run thro'
the heart and left dead on the field
The unfortunate Duke of rewsberry be-
came afterwards so irritAted as to challenge
the infamous Buckingham for intriguing
with his wife, and Buckingham ran him
through the body 1t was known that the
Duchess of Shrewsbury, in the disguise OF
page, attended her paramour to the held
and held his horse whilst he fought and muir
dered her husband. The unpripeipled
Charles in spite of every remonstrance from
the Queen, received the Duke of Bucking-
ham with open arms, after his brutal muir
der.


In the last sixty years we have collected
list of l72 dues, comprising 344 individu-
ais OF these sixty-Eine persons were Kill
led: in three duels, neither OF the combat
ants survived; 90 persons were wounded, 48
desperately and 48 slightly; and 1873 escap-
ed unhurt. Thus, rather more than one
fifth lost their lives, and nearly one-halt re-
ceived the bullets of their antagonists. 1t
appears also that 1s trials took place, six of
the arraigned were acquitted, seven found
guilty of mansaughter, and three of mur-
der, that two were executed, and eight i'm
prisoned for different periods.


In 1868, the Secretary of our Treasury,
| Mr.. Martin, notoriousy trained himself as
duelist, for the avowed purpose OF shoot
ing Mr.. Wilkes, whom he first insultcd in
the House of Commons, and afterwards
wounded in the Park. This gave rise to
Churchill's poem of "the Duelist." The
House of Commons ordered his Majesty's
Surgeon to attend Mr.. Wilkes, but Mr.. Mar
tin was considered to have done the state
much service. At that period it is to be re-
mark ed; that dnels were very fequent among
Clergymen. In 1864, the Rev. Mr.. Hill
was killed in duel by Cornet Gardener, OF
the Carbineers. The Rev. Mr.. Bate Dudley
fought two duels, and was afterwards, Gre
ated Knight by the King The Rev. Mr..
Allen killed Mr.. Dulancy in duel, in
Hyde Park, without mourning any ecclesias-
tcal censure, though Judge Rutler, on ac-
count of the extremely bad conduct OF the
Clergyman, strongly charged the Jury upon
| his guilt of murder. Whilst the King knight
ed the Rev. Sir Bate Dudley, after his two
Questionable ducls, condemned the Sieur Che
las, Member of Parliament in France, to be
broken upon the wheel for the murder of
Can't. Requin, the Sieur Chelais having COW
cred himself with armour under his clothes
and stabbed his antagonist whose sword
broke against his breast plate. In 1765, oc-
CURED the famous duel III which the father
of our late transcendant poet, Lord Byron,
killed the famous duelist Mr.. Chaworth.-
They quarreled at a club dinner at the Star
and Garter, Pall-mall, about game. Mr..
Chaworth being a great game preserver,
whilst Lord Byron argued upon the cruelty
and jmpoIicy of the Game Laws. They a.
greed to fight in an adjoing room by the
light of only one candle. Lord Byron enter
ed first. and as Mr. Chaworth was shut
ting the door turning his head round, he be-
held Lord Byron's sword half undrawn. lie
Immediately whipped his own weapon out,
and making lunge at his Lordshlp, ran 1t
through his wa!stcoat, conceiving that his
sword had gone through his body. But Lord
Byron closed and shortened his sword, stab
bed Mr. Chaworth in the belly. The chal-
lence had proceeded from Mr.. Chaworth.--
| ord Byron read his defence to the House
of Lords, and was found guilty of manslaueh-
ter; and upon the privilege Of his peerage
(for Peers are licenced homicides,) he was
discharged on paying his fees. In 1772,
Mr.. M'Lean was challenged and killed by
Mr. Cameron, and the mother Of Mr..
M'Iean on hearing of the shocking event, in
stantly lost her senses, while Miss MLoad
who was to have been married t. The de-
ceased, was seized with fits, and died in
three days.


In Mr.. Sheridan's duel with Mr.. Mat
thews, the parties cut and slashed at each
other, u la mode de Theatre, until Mr. Mat
thews left a part of his sword sticking in Mr'
Sheridan's ear. In the famous duel in which
Mr.. Riddle was killed. and Mr. Canning
ham severely wounded, the challenge by
mistake, had fallen in the first instance INTO
the hands Of Sir James Riddle, father to Mr.
Riddle, who had it delivered to him, and
did no more than provide surgeons for the
event. In 1869. Colonel LenoX was insulted
hv the Duke of y who told him, before
lajl the officers on the parade of St. James's
that he desired to derive no protection from
his rank of Prince, The Colonel according"
lv fought his Royal Highncss, it is said, with
cork bullets, but be that as it may, he con-
trived to disturb one of the huge rows of
curis, which it was then the fashion to wear

ne express stipulation or caution, are in


IVY nature of them, as sacred as if

full articles.article:
front, suffering not a little from the lbations
of the previous evening. The only eye he
had was directed to the bottle, as if anxious
to be better acquainted with it's contents
when suddenly with terrific report, out
flew the cork, followed by fair portion of
the angry liquid--both pursuing their course
so directly towards the unsuspecting optic,
that they fairly closed the poor son of Cris-
pins only inlet to daylight. The cork as
smartly rebounded. and striking the nose of
a knight of the shuttle reused him whilst
gaping obviously at the pulpit. The kirk
was all in buzz-and every mothers son,
ave daughter too, with out stretched neck
to ascertain the cause. The hussey,' ex-
claimed the blowsy wife o. Dollar, she's
poisoaed my caes' Preserve us, if she has
ia stickit the minister, whispered the horse
couper's wifc.--Jenny, as soon as she discov-
cred the cause of all this confusion, made
her thumb take the place of a cork-but un-


luckily proving either too large or too small
for stopper, the enraged BARN occasional


y made its escape, producing species OF
music that kept contemptuous time with
the doleful ditty of poor Jenny, as she hur'


riedly moved off, excaiming, preserve me,
was ever woman i'll sic a predccamint.

full articles.headline: From the LoRdon Observer.
full articles.article:
So frequent did duels become, that it is
said, in the short reign of Henry ". of
France, 1000 persons per!shed in duels.
Coke lays it down that duelling is strictly
contrary to the law Of England, and every
By -stander is enjoined to prevent duel. IT.,
in so doing, he injure the combatants, they
shall have no remedy at law; if he be hurt
by them, he shall have his redress, Not
wthstandins this, duelling in England was
carried to its greatest possible excess, IN


the reigns of James |. and ofthe two Charles'.
In the reign of the latter Charles, the Sc
conds always fought as well as their princl-


pals; and as they were chosen for their cour-
age and adrotness, their combats were gen


erally the most fatal. We read that Lord
Howard, of Carlisle, in the reign of Charles
II. gave grand fete chanpetre, at Spring
Gardens, near the village Of Charing. Spring
Gardens, was the Vauxhall of that day, and
the tete, in question was given to facilitate
an intrigue between Lord Howard and the
profligate Duches of sherry. But the

full articles.headline: .,r.nn, - s.;d country woman to
full articles.article:
"Jenny," said country woman to her
buxom daughter, during one OF the warm
mornings CT last summer, "Jennv, yen ava
to the town and bring hame battle o BARN
Tyeast1 wi you." 1t was the preaching days
with Jenny, aud having "trysted to meet her
Joe," she nodded an assent to her mother
commands, with a beam i'll her eye that
bespoke as much of, love as obedience
Having accordingly lost no time In display
ing her charms to the best advantage, she
plunged the quart bottle in among the sun
dries which never fail to occupy the capa
cious receptacle denominated by country
damsels, sidepocket, and so smartiy trip
ped her way to town, that she was halt way
on her return before the sun reached his
meridian. Whether it was that Jenny had
been seized with more than ordinary feelings
Of devotion, or that the willy god, being i'll a
frolicksome humour, had resolved on play
ing off one OF his pranks upon her. we shall
not pretend to say, but certain 1t is that
Jenny, on her way homewards, was just
passing the kirk as she got glimpse OF her
Joe stepping into it Regardless otthe we'll
corked bottle Of BARN, Jenny nstinctlvely
pursued the same course, and sat herself
down beside blowsy wife from Dollar, who
had travelled a dozen miles that morning to
hear the word in its purity, if not to retail
! it still more delectabiy, on her return, to the
drowthy gossps of her parish. Jenny had
scarcely time to look about her till the va
cant seat behind her was occupied by an e.
qually ponderous parsonage, in the shape OF
a horse couper's wife from the West. Had
Jenny been thinking more of her mother, and
less of her sweetheart, it is likely that il
would have occurred to her that so smart a
walk, and SO warm day, were sufficient te
have reused to a state of rebellion more
ouiescept matter than that which dangled by
her side, and in this way avoided bringing
its heat to the provoking temperature i'll.
duced by her own temperature on the one
side and that of the horse couper's wife OF
the other. Be these things as they may, the
heat which had commenced to seal Jenny:
eyes in peaceful slumbers, acted so power
fully on the turbulent properties of the
BARN, that an explosion was inevitable
Soon after Jenny had taken her seat the bot
!

full articles.headline: THE NATIVE HOME.
full articles.article:
Ireland.


81 was aroused from one OF memory S
sweetest dreams, by the distant sound OF
bells; they were those OF my native city
| had often heard them at the same hour,
they spoke of wo, devotion, and Joy, and
scenes long gone BY. In this sottened state
of feeling entered the town, and needless
of the throng, hurried on to the home OF
my parents-reaching the house--threw
myself into their arnis, and the first tumult
of feeling over. / sat at tbs e-side. with my
father Oh the one side. and my mother on
the other, gazing afectionate'y upon me,
while talked of all had seen, and all had
felt.


"Beng tired after my journey, my mother
suggested the propriety OF my gong 10 resi-
and the tender hand that had often smooth
cd my pillow, again performed that oihce'
could not help comparing my situation
with the nights that | had lain exposed to
the storm. with the cold earth for my bed,
and felt a lively gratitude, (worth thou
sand formal prayers) to the Divine Bcing,
who had watched over and protected me
thro' every danger, and brought me in safe
ty back to my home and parents.


"NVhile nv mind was occupied with these
reflections, my mother again entered my
chamber to sec if / wanted any thing. Are
you asleep, James, My eyes were shut
and did not reply. She stood over me witt
light iii her hand, gazing on my weather
beaten countenance.


My poor want.erer, she calculated
what must you have endured since
saw you--danger and death has surrounded
YOU fatigue ard hunger attended your steps
| but vet YOU have been kindly dealt with
mercifully preserved return thee thanks
thou Almighty giver of every good, tor thy
bountcous mercy to my poor boy-O snlit
him to thyself" I"


She stopped to kiss my forehead-he'
warm tear fell upon my face, my emotions
became too strong for concealment, and a.
fraid that she had disturbed my sleep, she
softly left the room.


Those who have felt the rude storms o.
adversely. and the endearing kindness OF
mother, will appreciate my feelings

full articles.headline:
From the London Monthly Magazine.
LONDON REMANETS.
full articles.article:
Men ALWAYS sympathise with the suffer-
ing of girls more than those other own sex.
"Reatlv. nv dear, | pity these poor girls,
the M'Tangles," said Mr. Partington to his
lady, as he peeped through his telescope on
the Margate Pier head, in the vain hope OF
catching little smoke in the horizon, from
which to infer the coming OF the Eclipse
steam vessel. "There they are broillng IN
town this whole blessed summer-you
should ask one OF them down." 30 saying,
Mr. Partington tilted his Chinese straw hat
little more over his brow to shade his eyes
from the burning glare of Phebus. "Wh ny
as to that, my dear" answered his wife, we
have daughters of our own to dispose OF -
and don't YOU remember how Sally VI Ian
| gle took the first in duett of Con un ARIA
with Colonel Nightingale, after he had tried
| it with our daughter Fanny, aud had found
that the poor girl could not get on with it'
I have never had good opinion OF the fam
| lily since" This, of course, settled the mat
ter.


A word with Mr.. Partington about his
phrase 'broiling in town. am a town man
myself, and think it my duty to stand up
for my own metropolis. Why should the
M'Tangles broil, because they happen to be
in town. For my part | can only say that
when was last at Ramsgate was broied
pretty handsomely. ! took walk upon the
! Lighthouse Pier, and light house pier 1t
was; nv face was like Lord Kelly's, whom
Foote solicited to lock over his garden wall
| to ripen his melons; Saint Laurence was a
sprat to me. On my return to town, took
a boat from Cherry Garden Stairs to White
hall; to do which had to walk down Bo-
tolph lane. The street was Delightfully."- mar
row, the sun could not enter, but a column
of air could; and I was regaled by the gar
den scent of oranges and lemons in the ad-
Joining warehouses. Let us hear no more ct
broiling in town. From that time forth |
have always set down my cause as Lon
don Remanet. The fact is. that Mrs.
M'Taugle has let me into her confidence,
knowing, that never published II met her
of all places in the world in private box at
Adelphia Theatre, witnessing the represen-
tation of Long Tom Coffin, by +. L. Cooke;
and very clever representation is. "You
never come near us now," eJaculated Mrs.
M'Tangle, in one of her most mellifluent
moods-Knowing that l was past praying
for in the matrimonial line, l felt puzzled
to account for this sudden predilection.--
However, it was settled that should dine
with her on the "Wednesday following. when
I accordingly met three or four young men
"a great deal too young for me, but by no
means too young for the Mesdemoisclles
M'Tangle. We had the usual lures. Tom
Gisbone, who had made good deal of mo-
ney by Mexican scrip, was asked by Miss
M'rangle if he would not have some love
sauce with his muffin pudding. George Ju
niper, rising wine and brandy merchant,
sang after dinner,


sMy spirits are mounting, my hearts full OF
glee,"-


(cause and effect in one line,) which Jane
M'Tangle pronounced to be the hest song
she ever heard in her life; and Sarah, the
youngest, undismayed by her former failure
in "Con un Aria," consented to take the first
in the "Witches' Glee," composed by King,
if Mr.. Parsons (son and heir to Sir Pere-
grine Parsons) would take the second.
found by comparing little circumstances to-

full articles.headline: THE EARL or BRlnGEwATER.
full articles.article:
The following probably overchargeu, Dut
curious account of this eccentric character,
appears in Paris paper Some persons
knowing but imperfectly this model of ori-
ginals, past, present, and to conc, appear
ed desirous to learn something more re-
spccting him; we thinktit may be agreeable,
if we collect such anecdotes respecting such
a singular parsonage as are well calculated
to enrich the history Of human oddities. No
one has higher claims to distinguished
place IN history, than Nj. Egerton, who has
for several years borne the name ot Lord
Bridgewater. Those who have once seen--
nay, those who have never seen this measre
parsonage drag himself along, supported
by two huge lacqueys, with his sugar-loat
hat souched down over his eyes, cannot tall
to recognize him.


An immense fortune enables him to graf
ify the most eXtravagant caprice that ever
passed through the head of an Engishnan,
II he be lent a book, he carries his poltencss
so far as to send 1t back or rather have it
conducted home in carriage. He gives
orders that two of his most stately steeds be
caparisoned. under one of his chariots and the
volume reclining at ease in mylord's lacdau
arrives, attended BY four footmcn in costly
livery, at the door of its astounded owner
His carriage is frequently to be seen filled
with his dogs. lie bcstows great care on
the feet Of these dogs, and orders them boots
for which he pays as dearly as his own.--
| Lord BridgeWater's custom is an excellent
one for the boot ker; for besides the foul
feet OF each of his dogs, the supply OF hi'
own two feet, must give constant employ
ment to several operatives. He puts on {
new pair OF boots every day; carefully pre-
serving those he has once worn, and ranging
them in order; he commands that none
shall touch them, but takes himself grea
pleasure in observing how much OF the yeal
he has each day past, by viewing the state
of his boots. Lord Egerton is a man of few
acquaintance, and very few of his country
men have got as far as the dining hall. Hi
table, however, is constantly set out with ;
dozen covers, and served by suitable at
tendance. Who, then are his privileged
guests? No less than a dozen Of favorltt
dogs, who daily partake of mylord's dinner
J seated very gravely in armed chairs, eacf
with napkin round his neck, and scrvan
behind to attend his wants.


These honorable quadrupcds as if CRATE
full for such delicate attentions, compor
themselves during the time OF repast with
| decency and 0ecorum which would do more
than honor to party of gentlemen; but if
by any chance, one OF them should, wlthou
due consideration, obey the natural instnc
of his appetite, and transgress any OF the
rules Of good manners, his punishment is a
hand. You perhaps, gentle reader, sup
pose that corporeal punishment is meant al
the walls OF the capital so eloquently but 81
Intellectually define 1t; but no--you are mis-
taken, tits ia his sclf-Iove that the offendel


is punished. The day following the day O
his offence, the dog dimes and even dine


we'll; but not at mylord's, and as becomes ;
dog to dine; banished to the ante-chamber
and dressed in livery, he eats in sorrow thu
bread of shame, and picks the bones of NOR
tifcation, while his place at table remain
vacant till his repentance has merited
generous pardon We have not been abl


to learn what dress Lord Egerton puts ol
his domestics, when he has cause to be dis
satisfied with their service

full articles.headline: FEBRUARY 8, 1927
full articles.article:
OF Mrs. M Tanglc's alteration OF me at the
Theatre. had observed Jane whispering
to her mother between the acts significantly,
and had overheard the words "Sing bass"
thought at the moment that this was meant
to apply to Long Tom Coffin, but now
found that was the hero of the side speech,
and that had been compimented with
knife and fork in Russell place, in order to
grumble out, when the hurly burly's done.'
Being in the main good natured man when
nothing occurs to vex me, made no objec-
ton, and away we started with, "When
shall we three meet again." as loud as If no
thing had happened After this l left the
three girls fumbling over music books in
quest OF 80 Patrian igrata." "You'll find
it among the loose SONGS" said Jane to Sa-
rah, where it occurred to me it had no busi-
ness to be. 1t farther occurred tc me that
my bass being ended, and there being
three girls and three young men, eX-
elusive of the author, l was one too
many. Accordingly, kind Mrs M'Tangle
called me into tho adjoining drawing room,
To get me out ofharm's way; and lett the
half dozen young ones pinned two and two
as Young ones should, looking over operas,
and hoping that Ncluti was not going to leave
US.


Mrs. M'Tanglc now let me little into
her plan. took my seatby her on the soia
and while crimson ottoman proppcd her
feet. She opened after the following fashion /:
-"rhis is the third year of my continuance
in town during the summer. After pref
tv regular run Of the watering places. found
I them all from July to September, overstock-
ed with other peoples daughters, possessed
of greater personal attractions than NINE
| One warm morning was coming the mat
ter over with Mr.. M'Tangle, at Donaldson's
library, when it suddenly occurred to me,
that Iondon in the autumn, from the absence
of competitors, would give the girls rea-
! snnable chance. i mentioned the matter to
Mr.. M'Tangle who caught at the idea with
alacrity. Poor man! he never liked the sea
side. The sun put ont his eyes, and the alb
sence Of his day book and ledger gave him
the yellow jaundcc. We accordingly re-
solved to adhere to Russell place, Fltzroy
square, through good and evil report, from
wears end to years end. The scheme has,
ain glad to say, hitherto succeeded. Young
men are delighted with dinner invitations IN
Scntember and October; and when you once
have them, you keep them" True, answer
! ed I but what species of young men? Peo.
nile Of fashion are killing game hundred
miles off. "people Of fashion, people OF fid-
die stick!' retorted Mrs. M'tansle. Al
/ have no taste tor the Lord CharleScs and
Lord Johns. Give me income. There is a
considerable portion of good marriageahle
material in the Excise and Customs, and a
bout the Royal Exchange. Peop'e occupied
there must be in town during great part OF
the autumnal season. have procured two
SONS in law, who came hither courting,
with their legs pendent from the top OF the
Tallyho Paddi1gton coach, their descent.
they had only to cross Fitzroy Square, and
here they were. You may rey upon it sir,
the true way of attaching society is to give
Rishy pfgflIy approve approve Of your plan, madam, an
swered j, rising to take my leave will re-
commend its adoption to Adrman Hunger
ford, now on his travels to Greece in quest
of Liberty and the picturesque. lie has
seven marriageabe daughters. Our young
counyrymen are fiocking to Athens in shoa $
"a dinner i'll the Acropols will infallibly dc


the business.

full articles.headline:
sDmsnzEFt0Ew


.GAy.ll Il. Af5 - D

soSii.
full articles.article:
aThe sun does not gladden. a moment so sweet
mo moon does not shine on so lovely an hour,
hsthe s,ft one where. light and obscurity meet,
And the world is half veiPd by its shadowy


power.
"Vhen the dew drops are glittering SO silent


and fair,


And the waters yet glow with the SUMS latest


ray,
Heaven breathcs It's repose in the calm twilight


air,


Unknown to the brightness and tumult of day
mTis moment to bid even wretchcdness cease;
A charm that can rob gloomy care OF his pow


er,
How balmy and sweet is the season of peace!
How tleart to my soul is the mild twilight hour!''
The woes of the present are mngling fast
with the hopes of the future the light OF the


past;
And o. Joy y-breathing moments, ere yet they are


,nirS,
Give place to the weary and sorrowful hours!
But fine, the destroyer, vet kindly shall bring
charm for each self suffering, balm for each


sting;
And the tear drop ofanguish while yetin its flow,
Is driel by the warmth Of Hopes heavenly glow.
And orr loys and our sorrows still blend as they


fade
In the rainbow oflifc to one mellowing shades
For the sunshine that glstcns on Grief's sullen


stream
Atones for the darkness it gild's with its beam.

Where is there vision sweeter


Than u boy and happy mother
lie makes her hours fly the fieeter:


She can all his sorrows smother.
What a look is that she gives him,


When he curves his arm around her!
Oh, her very soul receives him.


The bliss Of heaven sure has bound her!
Sec him lean his cheek, so smiling,


On her lap--and raise his lashes;
Mark bis hand, the time bcguiling,


With her ear-drop's dancing flashes.
Little knows the fair hard fellow,


She is asking God for blessings;
When her blossom, ripe, and mellow,


Will not have her kind caresslngs.
Little is that mother dreaming


Of his grief, when he must mingle,
Where no parent will be beamlng--


Where each heart is cold and single!
But, alas!-ne'r think of grieving,


While so sweet pictures glowing
Thoughts Of home we should be weaving
Pray'rs Of hope should now be howing!--

full articles.headline: From Mrs. Coinn's Mcsscnger,
full articles.article:
THE BEE AND SNAIL.
Apamper'd Snail began to crawl,
one May-morn, o'er garden wall,
And lettering long, and sauntering slow,
Awiv'd at noon where roses blow.
Close TO the roses stood hive,
From whence the swarm, alert, alive,
Intent for honey, thick as hail,
PasS'd often DER the basking snail.
Labor ynir Snail superbly scorns;
tor ccronel mistaking horns,
And 'city strut of Incidence,
tM ,ghlty and great good sense.
A'e npiish'd thus, our grave grandee,
ny 'tnsth accosts u busy Bee:
why labor, insect, one would think
10 susal-slaves, is meat and drink.
Next to the silk-hy we affirm
Thou art the most laborious worm:
me Caterpillar spins her clothes,
ana thou spin'st syrup from the rose.
Al an wretched avarice works thee wo,
AZ that mars all happiness below"
EOS 30 snail, the industrious Bee replies,
s,,.l, svli heaping honey on his thighs:
rWhy snail, yon lavish life away,
troubled by languor and decay,
w una DOING; while you stretch your horns,
we we suck the rose unhurt by thorns,
Extract from blossoms affluent store,
ffiowers all left fragrant as before.
sse Ns.s OF light labor crowns our wish,
w.. u.'ar our meat, and wax our dish.
NJ NJ. you and yours, in shine or shower,
a,oie ,na the stem and faint the flower,
Na,a ;,a s'umber precious life away,


AT stih the sunshine making hay


ii.a ,a pehce ne the Snails, when frosts unfold,


peggars, die of want or cold.


4onts 4Itsn auarice be sometimes curse,


=" 'u@'nsss is ten times Worse.

out anr trusts of confidence, though will


ne ". wy. express stipulation or caution, are


Ivy nature of them, as sacred as

full articles.headline: No. 81.
full articles.article:
Duchess, and distracted all her attentions
with his lordship; and ridiculing the tete, his
/ lordship was hardly restrained from running
him through the body before the company.
The next day his lordship sent challenge
to Sidney. The former chose as his second,
tell, furious, adroit swordsman, named
Dillon; and the latter selected young gen.
tleman, named Rawlings, just come into pos
session of an estate of ten thousand pounds
year.-Sidney was wounded i'll two OF
three places, whilst his second was run thro'
the heart and left dead on the field
The unfortunate Duke of rewsberry be-
came afterwards so irritAted as to challenge
the infamous Buckingham for intriguing
with his wife, and Buckingham ran him
through the body 1t was known that the
Duchess of Shrewsbury, in the disguise OF
page, attended her paramour to the held
and held his horse whilst he fought and muir
dered her husband. The unpripeipled
Charles in spite of every remonstrance from
the Queen, received the Duke of Bucking-
ham with open arms, after his brutal muir
der.


In the last sixty years we have collected
list of l72 dues, comprising 344 individu-
ais OF these sixty-Eine persons were Kill
led: in three duels, neither OF the combat
ants survived; 90 persons were wounded, 48
desperately and 48 slightly; and 1873 escap-
ed unhurt. Thus, rather more than one
fifth lost their lives, and nearly one-halt re-
ceived the bullets of their antagonists. 1t
appears also that 1s trials took place, six of
the arraigned were acquitted, seven found
guilty of mansaughter, and three of mur-
der, that two were executed, and eight i'm
prisoned for different periods.


In 1868, the Secretary of our Treasury,
| Mr.. Martin, notoriousy trained himself as
duelist, for the avowed purpose OF shoot
ing Mr.. Wilkes, whom he first insultcd in
the House of Commons, and afterwards
wounded in the Park. This gave rise to
Churchill's poem of "the Duelist." The
House of Commons ordered his Majesty's
Surgeon to attend Mr.. Wilkes, but Mr.. Mar
tin was considered to have done the state
much service. At that period it is to be re-
mark ed; that dnels were very fequent among
Clergymen. In 1864, the Rev. Mr.. Hill
was killed in duel by Cornet Gardener, OF
the Carbineers. The Rev. Mr.. Bate Dudley
fought two duels, and was afterwards, Gre
ated Knight by the King The Rev. Mr..
Allen killed Mr.. Dulancy in duel, in
Hyde Park, without mourning any ecclesias-
tcal censure, though Judge Rutler, on ac-
count of the extremely bad conduct OF the
Clergyman, strongly charged the Jury upon
| his guilt of murder. Whilst the King knight
ed the Rev. Sir Bate Dudley, after his two
Questionable ducls, condemned the Sieur Che
las, Member of Parliament in France, to be
broken upon the wheel for the murder of
Can't. Requin, the Sieur Chelais having COW
cred himself with armour under his clothes
and stabbed his antagonist whose sword
broke against his breast plate. In 1765, oc-
CURED the famous duel III which the father
of our late transcendant poet, Lord Byron,
killed the famous duelist Mr.. Chaworth.-
They quarreled at a club dinner at the Star
and Garter, Pall-mall, about game. Mr..
Chaworth being a great game preserver,
whilst Lord Byron argued upon the cruelty
and jmpoIicy of the Game Laws. They a.
greed to fight in an adjoing room by the
light of only one candle. Lord Byron enter
ed first. and as Mr. Chaworth was shut
ting the door turning his head round, he be-
held Lord Byron's sword half undrawn. lie
Immediately whipped his own weapon out,
and making lunge at his Lordshlp, ran 1t
through his wa!stcoat, conceiving that his
sword had gone through his body. But Lord
Byron closed and shortened his sword, stab
bed Mr. Chaworth in the belly. The chal-
lence had proceeded from Mr.. Chaworth.--
| ord Byron read his defence to the House
of Lords, and was found guilty of manslaueh-
ter; and upon the privilege Of his peerage
(for Peers are licenced homicides,) he was
discharged on paying his fees. In 1772,
Mr.. M'Lean was challenged and killed by
Mr. Cameron, and the mother Of Mr..
M'Iean on hearing of the shocking event, in
stantly lost her senses, while Miss MLoad
who was to have been married t. The de-
ceased, was seized with fits, and died in
three days.


In Mr.. Sheridan's duel with Mr.. Mat
thews, the parties cut and slashed at each
other, u la mode de Theatre, until Mr. Mat
thews left a part of his sword sticking in Mr'
Sheridan's ear. In the famous duel in which
Mr.. Riddle was killed. and Mr. Canning
ham severely wounded, the challenge by
mistake, had fallen in the first instance INTO
the hands Of Sir James Riddle, father to Mr.
Riddle, who had it delivered to him, and
did no more than provide surgeons for the
